text: let's take a look at what's new with AWS
IIM identity Center
for current AWS SSL customers there is
no change to how you essentially manage
access to multiple AWS accounts or
applications the name change reflects
the service capabilities foundation in
AWS identity and access management and
role as central place to manage access
across AWS
the console has been updated with
cosmetic changes to reflect the new name
we've also updated the documentation to
also reflect the new name what is not
changing is the functionality apis and
the CLI to ensure backwards
compatibility
let's take a look at the console as we
walk through the console you'll notice
that the changes we've made are
primarily around the cosmetics
as we step through the console we'll
take a look at the user section
next let's take a look at groups
and finally let's take a look at the
settings
here you can see in the settings the Arn
still says SSO let's take a look at the

see your AWS organizations with all your
accounts
here we're in permission sets and one of
the new features that we have in
permission sets is the ability to
support customer managed policies and
permission boundaries let's step through
and take a look
here you can see customer managed
policies
let's go ahead and attach the sample
policy
here we enter the policy name not Bay
Arn
if we scroll down we see the permissions
boundary and again we can set the
permissions boundary for a role
here we select customer managed policy
and we put in the policy name
this is the policy name that you would
see inside the AWS IIM console
jumping ahead to Applications identity
Center can support multiple applications
any custom application that supports
saml 2.0

account supported and if we go through

using a terminal
